awd_titl_txt: Bioinspiration and Biodiversity Workshop; Brunei, Borneo; 16-22 December 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will provide funding for 30 people, many of which are from under-represented groups, the opportunity to attend a workshop on Bioinspiration and Biodiversity in Brunei, Borneo, 16-22 December 2019. Participants will attend plenary lectures on emerging topics in this area, participate in road mapping exercises, and conduct field work in the rich and diverse environment of Brunei, Borneo. There will be plenary lectures in emerging topics such as specimen digitization, data analytics, computational analysis of biological functions, and bioinspired robotics. Road mapping exercises will be conducted in the areas of foundations, digitization, data analytics, hardware paradigms, interdisciplinary education, and team building and research program development. The workshop will also include related field studies.

This workshop will provide an excellent opportunity for US researchers to form collaborations with some of the foremost biodiversity experts in Southeast Asia. Early career researchers will be trained at this workshop and will have outstanding networking opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
Bioinspiration is an emerging field of engineering that seeks to
discover new solutions for technical problems from the study of
biological systems. Some well-known examples of everyday technologies
that have been derived from insights into biological function are
hook-and-loop fasteners ("Velcro") and the motion sensor circuit of
the optical mouse. However, these individual success stories have been
to a large extent gifts of serendipity and bioinspiration has yet to
mature into an engineering approach that can mine the world's
biodiversity for engineering knowledge in a systematic fashion.

The goal of the NSF-sponsored workshop on "bioinspiration and
biodiversity" has been to chart a roadmap for this transformation of
bioinspiration. To do so, the workshop participants have explored ways
to exploit the ecological and evolutionary nexus that connects all
biological species for the benefit of bioinspired engineering. In
biology, these connections are commonly used in a "comparative
approach" to untangle the effects of evolutionary heritage from those
of ecological adaptation. In contrast to this, bioinspired engineering
has been largely limited to isolated case studies. This not only a
major obstacle to the correct interpretation of biological function,
but also looses the opportunity to search systematically for matching
biological model systems and to gain insight into how a single
functional principle may be adopted for different uses.

To exploit this evolutionary/biodiversity perspective for bioinspired
engineering, the workshop has delved deeply into the use of
state-of-the-art digitization methods that could give engineers
detailed quantitative data on complex biological function across
multiple species. Computational methods that can predict function from
form, e.g., by predicting the aerodynamics of a flapping animal wing,
can be combined with the biological data to infer much more about
biological function than is immediately accessible from the
experimental observations. Automation of biological observations
combined with highly efficient computational methods could produce
extremely large data sets that would support discovery of new
functional principles of technological value. However, the size,
complex nature, and large variability of such biological and
derivative data would have posed an insurmountable challenge for data
analytics until very recently. Now, the ongoing deep-learning
revolution offers a novel opportunity to to discover the patterns
underlying such data and hence make the outcomes of biological
evolution readable to engineering.

Hence, the workshop has charted a path for how the convergence of
digitization, computational analysis, AI data analytics and a
comparative approach derived from classical biology and adopted for
modern engineering could realize the potential to transform the
world's biodiversity into a natural resource for the 21st century
knowledge economy. Doing so would make the results of the evolutionary
optimization process that exceed the scale of any human effort by many
orders magnitude along multiple dimensions (e.g., time, space,
species, individuals) accessible for engineers to address the complex
technological issues of the present and future leading to technologies
that can address humanities needs - in smarter more sustainable ways.

The workshop has been attended by over 50 faculty-level researchers,
more than half of which were engineers from various universities the
US. Since the workshop was held in Brunei, where the campus of the
local host university is efficiently connected to some of the world's
most biodiverse habitats, it was possible to expose the engineering
faculty to biodiversity first-hand and under guidance from local and
regional biodiversity experts. This has made an important contribution
to educate US engineering faculty on the potential value of
biodiversity for engineering and give them a clear picture of the
challenges involved in mining biodiversity for technology-relevant
knowledge.

 


Last Modified: 01/01/2024
Modified by: Rolf Mueller

Image
  • Examples of the field activities conducted during the workshop on biodiversity and bioinspiration that were designed to expose engineering faculty to biodiversity.
    Rolf Mueller
